hebrew.meaning: Hosts, armies. Used in the divine title 'YHWH Tzevaot' (LORD of Hosts), emphasizing God's supreme command over all heavenly armies (angels) and earthly powers.
Eternity, age, forever, ancient times. Conveys a sense of indefinite and perpetual time, both past and future. 'Le-Olam Va-Ed' means 'forever and ever'.
To save, to deliver, to be liberated. The root verb for names like Joshua, Isaiah, and Jesus. It implies rescue from a narrow or tight place.
Righteousness, justice. Often used in a legal or relational sense, meaning to be in the right. 'Tzedakah' is the noun form for righteousness/charity.
Evil, badness, calamity, distress. Can refer to moral evil, natural evil, or simply something that is not good or pleasant.
Prayer, intercession, supplication. The standard Hebrew word for communication with God.
Holy, sacred, set apart. The fundamental attribute of God, denoting His absolute otherness, purity, and separation from sin. 'Kedoshim' means 'holy ones' or 'saints'.
To fear, to revere, to be in awe. 'The fear of the LORD' (Yirat YHWH) is the foundation of wisdom, meaning a reverential awe and respect that leads to obedience.
God; a plural noun (im suffix) often used with singular verbs, emphasizing majesty, power, and the plurality within the Godhead. Used especially in creation narratives.

The sacred, personal, and covenantal name of the God of Israel. Revealed to Moses at the burning bush, derived from the verb 'hayah' (to be), meaning 'He Who Is' or 'I AM'. Often translated as 'LORD' (in small caps).
Lord, Master. A title of respect and sovereignty for God. Jews often read this word in place of the sacred name YHWH.
Spirit, wind, breath. Denotes the powerful, invisible, and life-giving force of God. 'Ruach Elohim' is the Spirit of God hovering over creation.
To create, to shape. This verb almost exclusively has God as its subject, denoting divine, ex nihilo (out of nothing) creation.
Covenant, pact, treaty. A central theme of the Bible, describing God's binding agreements with humanity (e.g., Noah, Abraham, David) and Israel at Sinai.
Anointed One; a person consecrated by having oil poured on their head, set apart for a special role like king (Saul, David) or priest. The ultimate 'Messiah' is the promised redeemer.
Glory, weight, heaviness, honor. Refers to the tangible and visible manifestation of God's majestic presence, often described as a consuming fire or brilliant cloud.
Steadfast love, lovingkindness, mercy, covenant loyalty. One of the most important words describing God's character: His unwavering, faithful, and loyal love for His covenant people.
Truth, firmness, faithfulness. It signifies something that is reliable, stable, and true. Often paired with 'Hesed' (lovingkindness and truth).
Peace; but far more than the absence of conflict. It signifies completeness, wholeness, health, welfare, safety, and prosperity. A state of holistic flourishing.
Soul, life, person, self, appetite. Not a disembodied spirit, but the whole living being, the 'self' or 'life-force' of a person or animal.
Heart. In Hebrew thought, the center of the intellect, will, and emotions—the core of a person's moral and spiritual life.
Return, repentance. The act of turning away from sin and returning to God. A key concept in the prophetic literature.
Assembly, congregation, community. The gathered people of God.

latin.meaning: Incarnation. Literally 'becoming in flesh' (in + caro/flesh). The doctrine that the Son of God took on human flesh in Jesus Christ.
Trinity. The foundational Christian doctrine of one God in three co-equal, co-eternal Persons: Father, Son (Verbum), and Holy Spirit (Spiritus Sanctus).
Image of God. The teaching that humanity is created in the image and likeness of God, conferring unique dignity and purpose.
Lamb of God. A title for Jesus, identifying Him as the perfect and final sacrificial lamb who takes away the sin of the world.
'A voice of one crying in the wilderness'. A famous phrase from the Vulgate describing John the Baptist's ministry.
Completion, fulfillment. The final completion and restoration of all things at the end of the age.
Word. Used in the Vulgate for the Greek 'Logos' in John 1:1, 'In principio erat Verbum'.
Grace, favor. The foundational concept of unmerited divine assistance for salvation.
Peace. The standard Latin translation for the Greek 'Eirēnē' and Hebrew 'Shalom'. Used in the common benediction 'Pax vobiscum' (Peace be with you).
Savior. A key title for Christ, meaning 'one who saves'.
Charity, love. In the Vulgate, this is Jerome's primary translation for the Greek 'Agapē', emphasizing its self-giving nature.
Church. A direct borrowing from the Greek 'Ekklēsia'.
Gospel. A direct borrowing from the Greek 'Euangelion'.
Spirit, breath. 'Spiritus Sanctus' is the Holy Spirit.
Justification. A key theological term from the Vulgate, meaning 'to declare righteous'. This Latin term heavily influenced Western theology (e.g., in Luther's 'justification by faith').
Redemption. The act of buying back, delivering, or liberating at a cost. Central to the concept of Christ's work on the cross.
Sacrament. In the Vulgate, it originally meant 'mystery' or 'oath'. Later, in Christian theology, it came to denote a sacred rite that is an outward sign of inward grace.
'Common' or 'Popular'. The name for St. Jerome's 4th-century Latin translation of the Bible, which became the standard version for the Roman Catholic Church.

greek.meaning: God, deity. The standard word for God or a god.
Lord, master. The title used for Jesus, identifying Him with the YHWH of the Old Testament. A confession of His divinity.
Jesus; the Greek form of the Hebrew name Joshua/Yehoshua, meaning 'Yahweh is salvation'.
Christ, Anointed One. The Greek translation of 'Mashiach'. It became the fundamental title for Jesus of Nazareth.
Spirit, wind, breath. 'Pneuma Hagion' means Holy Spirit.
Word, reason, principle. In John's Gospel, it is a title for Jesus, identifying Him as the ultimate self-expression and rational principle of God, through whom all things were created.
Love, specifically self-sacrificial, divine love. It is the nature of God (1 John 4:8) and the highest form of love commanded of believers.
Grace, favor, gift. The unmerited and free gift of God's salvation and favor through Jesus Christ.
Faith, belief, trust, faithfulness. It encompasses intellectual assent, personal trust, and loyal obedience.
Peace. The Greek equivalent of the Hebrew 'Shalom', signifying wholeness and well-being, especially reconciliation with God through Christ.
Sin. Literally 'to miss the mark'. It signifies a failure to live up to God's standard, a state of rebellion and brokenness.
Salvation, deliverance, rescue. Refers to being saved from sin and its consequences, and brought into a state of wholeness and eternal life.
Righteousness, justice. The state of being in right relationship with God and others. It is a gift from God received through faith.
Church, assembly. A body of people 'called out' from the world to belong to God. The universal body of Christ and its local expressions.
Gospel, good news. The proclamation of the life, death, burial, and resurrection of Jesus Christ, through which salvation is offered.
Life. Often used in the New Testament for 'eternal life' (zōē aiōnios), which is a quality of life in relationship with God that begins now and continues forever.
Flesh. Can mean the physical body, but often used by Paul to denote the sinful, fallen human nature opposed to God.
Cross. The instrument of Roman execution which became the central symbol of Christian faith, representing Christ's sacrificial death.
Helper, Advocate, Comforter. A legal term for someone called to one's aid. Jesus uses it for the Holy Spirit who will come alongside believers.
Mystery. Not a secret to be kept, but a divine truth formerly hidden and now revealed in Christ and the Gospel.
To repent. Literally 'to change one's mind/nous'. It signifies a profound turning around—a change of mind, heart, and direction away from sin and toward God.
Hope. In the NT, not a vague wish but a confident and certain expectation of future good, based on the promises of God.
Obedience, submission. The act of hearing and heeding; the proper response to faith.
Authority, power, right. Denotes the legal right or authority to act, as opposed to raw power (dynamis). Jesus taught with 'exousia'.
Body. Refers to the physical body, but also to a collective body like the Church, which is the 'Sōma of Christ'.
Age, eternity. A period of time, often with a specific character. 'Eis ton aiōna' means 'unto the age' or 'forever'.
Kingdom, reign, rule. The central theme of Jesus' preaching: the active reign and sovereignty of God, which has broken into the world through Him.
To cause to stumble, to offend. The origin of the English 'scandalize'. It means to put a stumbling block in someone's path, causing them to sin or lose faith.

aramaic.meaning: Father, Daddy. An intimate, familiar term for one's father. Jesus used it to address God, and it signifies the believer's intimate relationship with God through Christ.
Our Lord, come! An early Christian Aramaic prayer expressing hope for the return of Jesus Christ.
Empty-headed, fool, worthless. A term of contempt that Jesus warns against using in the Sermon on the Mount.
Little girl, arise. The words spoken by Jesus when raising Jairus's daughter from the dead.
My God, my God, why have you forsaken me? The cry of Jesus from the cross, quoting Psalm 22.
Passover. The Aramaic (and Greek) term for the Passover festival. This is the root for words like 'Paschal' (relating to Easter).
Reward of God. The name of the respected Pharisee and teacher of Paul who counseled caution regarding the apostles.
Gate, door. Used in the Aramaic sections of Daniel.
